column1: #Text=Loch Lomond and The Trossachs National Park
#Text=Loch Lomond and The Trossachs National Park
#Text=straddles the two regions of the Scottish Highlands and the Central Belt of Scotland .
#Text=Scotland 's first national park is located north-west of Glasgow with train access at Balloch , Arrochar/ Tarbet , Ardlui and Crainlarich .
#Text=It is divided into four distinct areas :
#Text=is the largest loch in Scotland , the largest body of fresh water in Britain and probably the most famous after Loch Ness .
#Text=The southern end of the loch is quite flat , but the scenery soon becomes more mountainous and distinctly wild by the time you reach the north end .
#Text=, Loch Katrine and Loch Array are in the north-east
#Text=There is one national park visitor centre :
#Text=, Balmaha , G63 OJQ ( in the pretty village of Balmaha , East Loch Lomond ) , ☏ +441389722100 .
#Text=A stop-off point for walkers on the West Highland Way , local produce and top-up supplies .
#Text=— located at the southern end of Loch Lomond , it is the main town on the loch , and can get busy .
#Text=The Loch Lomond Shores TIC/visitors centre can help you plan your stay and provide you with close-area maps .
#Text=— a town without any attractions other than its beautiful appearance and cottages , which are still worth a visit .
#Text=— this village makes a great base to explore Ben Lomond .
#Text=— good base for the Conic Hill , also a nice pub ( claimed to be the oldest in Scotland ) and Buchanan castle .
#Text=— a large village near the centre of the west shore with railway station
#Text=— the largest island in the loch
#Text=The Loch Lomond and the Trossachs National Park was the first national park established in Scotland .
#Text=It became fully operational on 19 July 2002 and was officially opened by Princess Anne on 24 July 2002 .
#Text=The National Park encompasses around 720 sq miles ( 1,865 km ) of land including the Loch Lomond area and The Trossachs region .
#Text=local trains run frequently from Glasgow ' s Queen Street Station low level to Balloch which is at the end of the line , taking about 50 minutes , with generally two trains per hour .
#Text=The station in Balloch is easy to find .
#Text=Several trains run daily between Glasgow and Oban , Fort William and Mallaig which stop at Tarbet and Ardlui on the north-west shore and at Crainlarich in the northern part of the park .
#Text=These leave from the upper level of Glasgow 's Queen Street station .
#Text=The Caledonian Sleeper from London also runs up here .
#Text=, Arrochar / Tarbet , Ardlui , Crianlarich , Tyndrum are all on the West Highland Railway , which has around three trains per day from Glasgow Queen Street main level to Oban and Fort William .
#Text=The A82 road up the shore of Loch Lomond is used by the Citylink buses ( 3 per day ) from Glasgow to Fort William .
#Text=Citylink buses from Glasgow to Campbeltown go up Loch Lomond as far as Tarbet and then pass Arrochar and Cairndow on the way to Inveraray .
#Text=Citylink buses from Edinburgh via Stirling to Fort William pass Callander and Crianlarich .
#Text=Buses run frequently between Balloch and Glasgow .
#Text=From Oban follow the A85 , which runs parallel to the train line , and you will enter the park from its north-western boundary .
#Text=On this route you also pass by Kilchurn Castle at Lake Awe .
#Text=From Stirling follow the A84 and you will enter the park from its eastern boundary at Callander .
#Text=No permit is required to enter the park or explore on foot , by bicycle or by road .
#Text=Permits may be required for fishing , or some boat use .
#Text=An excellent reference tool for planning your journey is the travelinescotland website and journey planner for all bus , rail , coach , air and ferry services in Scotland .
#Text=Buses run along Loch Lomand , but not that frequently .
#Text=You should check the departure-times first , as timetable are not usually available at the stops .
#Text=The National Park Authority publishes a timetable of all the buses and ferries which may be available as a booklet locally .
#Text=If you 're driving , mind that the road along the northern part of Loch Lomond is pretty narrow for the traffic it has .
#Text=Sightseeing trips by boat on Loch Lomond run from Loch Lomond Shores near Balloch .
#Text=There is also a useful passenger ferry between Inverbeg ( served by Citylink buses ) and Rowardennan ( at the foot of Ben Lomond mountain ) .
#Text=The steamship SS Sir Walter Scott offers cruises on Loch Katrine in the Trossachs .
#Text=There are connecting buses from Callander and Stirling for some services .
#Text=To enjoy the nature , it is best to go by bike .
#Text=There 's a ( relatively ! ) well-maintained and -signposted cycleway from Glasgow to Balloch called National Route 7 .
#Text=A good place to join it is Bells Bridge over the Clyde by the SECC ( Scottish Exhibition and Conference Center ) .
#Text=( From Glasgow follow signs on M8 for Aberfoyle .
#Text=From Stirling/Callander follow A81 to Aberfoyle via Dukes Pass ) .
#Text=, Killin ( Easily reached from Aberfeldy and Kenmore ( via the A827 along the shores of Loch Tay ) , and from Crianlarich and Lochearnhead ( via the A85 and A827 ) ) .
#Text=Overlooks The Falls of Dochart at the western end of Killin .
#Text=Discover the story of Scotland 's ' High Country ' .
#Text=A hiking trail starting in Lochearnhead is described on walkhighlands .
#Text=, Lake of Menteith ( along the A81 ) , ☏ +441877385294 .
#Text=An Augustinian monastery on an island , where Mary Stuart once hid from Henry VIII .
#Text=A ferry runs to the island , but is only operated in summer .
#Text=Lake of Menteith is one of the very few lakes in Scotland referred to as " lake " and not as " loch " .
#Text=( North of Loch Lommond on the A82 and the West Highland Way
#Text=A beautiful town with four walks around town and a sandy beach .
#Text=A map can be picked up at Balloch TIC or at the Luss Visitor Information .
